text: I'm curious how you guys use flumine, whether you have a lot of your own custom code in there or if you use the libraries extensively. I ask because I got tons of my own code, classes and functions to get it up and running how I need it, but only because I am a laymen when it comes to understanding how flumine works and don't really know how to utilise its potential.

elements.text: I'm curious how you guys use flumine, whether you have a lot of your own custom code in there or if you use the libraries extensively. I ask because I got tons of my own code, classes and functions to get it up and running how I need it, but only because I am a laymen when it comes to understanding how flumine works and don't really know how to utilise its potential.

text: I'll second that notion Adrian.  At this stage I am still far more comfortable with my own code, although I have finally implemented somethign with betfairlightweight.

text: Thanks Andy. Have you tried flumine? I think it's amazing but I know i'm only scratching the surface

text: I've only looked at it to be honest.  It's one of those things that I knew was going to need plenty of focus to get my head around, but now that we have gone into lockdown, I'll start to dig around in it and see what I can come up with.

elements.text: I've only looked at it to be honest.  It's one of those things that I knew was going to need plenty of focus to get my head around, but now that we have gone into lockdown, I'll start to dig around in it and see what I can come up with.

text: <@U01S1VB9X9P> for me it's a point of principle not to load Flumine strategies up with a ton of my own code. I view my strategies as infinite loops executing the same code over and over, so want that code to be as lightweight as possible. Whenever Flumine has a helper that does what I need, I use it in preference to writing my own as they often deal with edge cases that I might not have thought of, and moreover, it makes the code more maintainable for when future me comes back to it later needing to make adjustments. That doesn't mean I don't have some quite complex processing, but when it starts to get too complex, that's often a sign that I'm overthinking the strategy itself.
